kitchen_cleaning: Start with decluttering surfaces before deep cleaning to make the process more manageable
Use the 'top to bottom' rule - clean higher surfaces first so debris falls to lower areas
Keep cleaning supplies in a caddy or bucket for easy transport between areas
Clean as you cook to prevent buildup and reduce overwhelming cleanup sessions
Use warm water and dish soap for most surfaces - it's gentle but effective
Set a timer for each task to avoid spending too much time on one area
Play upbeat music or podcasts to make cleaning more enjoyable and maintain energy
bathroom_cleaning: Spray surfaces with cleaner and let them sit while you clean other areas for better results
Use an old toothbrush for detailed cleaning around faucets and tile grout
Clean mirrors and glass surfaces last to avoid streaking from other cleaning products
Keep rubber gloves handy to protect your hands and make you feel more comfortable
Replace toilet brushes regularly for better hygiene and effectiveness
Use a squeegee on shower walls after each use to prevent water spots and mildew
Ventilate the area well during and after cleaning to prevent chemical buildup
laundry: Set phone alarms for washing and drying cycles to prevent clothes from sitting too long
Sort clothes as you undress throughout the week to make laundry day easier
Keep a stain removal pen or spray bottle handy for immediate treatment
Fold or hang clothes immediately after drying to prevent wrinkles and re-washing
Use mesh bags for delicate items and small items like socks to prevent loss
Keep a 'dry cleaning' bag in your closet for items that need special care
Do smaller, more frequent loads rather than letting laundry pile up
organization: Start with one small area or drawer rather than tackling an entire room at once
Use the 'one in, one out' rule to prevent accumulation of unnecessary items
Label containers and shelves to make it easier to maintain organization
Set up systems that match your natural habits rather than fighting against them
Use clear containers when possible so you can see what's inside without opening
Schedule short 10-15 minute daily tidying sessions to prevent major cleanups
Take before and after photos to celebrate your progress and stay motivated
general_tips: Break large tasks into smaller, more manageable chunks to reduce overwhelm
Use timers to create urgency and prevent tasks from taking longer than necessary
Reward yourself after completing tasks to build positive associations
Keep a 'done' list alongside your to-do list to track accomplishments
Use body doubling - clean alongside a friend, family member, or virtual companion
Create a cleaning playlist with your favorite energizing songs
Remember that 'good enough' is better than perfect - done is better than perfect
motivation: Focus on how you'll feel after the task is complete rather than the effort required
Connect the task to your values - a clean space supports your well-being
Use positive self-talk and avoid harsh criticism during the process
Celebrate small wins and progress, not just final completion
Remember that maintaining habits is easier than constantly restarting
Find an accountability partner or use apps to track your progress
Practice self-compassion when tasks don't go as planned - tomorrow is a new day
adhd_specific: Use visual timers to better understand time passage during tasks
Keep supplies visible and easily accessible to reduce barriers to starting
Use the 'dopamine sandwich' approach - pair boring tasks with enjoyable activities
Take movement breaks every 15-20 minutes to maintain focus and energy
Use external reminders like phone alarms, sticky notes, or apps
Create specific homes for items to reduce the mental load of deciding where things go
Work with your energy levels - tackle harder tasks when you feel most alert
autism_specific: Establish consistent routines and stick to the same order of operations when possible
Use noise-canceling headphones if auditory sensitivity affects your cleaning
Choose cleaning products with scents and textures that feel comfortable to you
Create detailed step-by-step lists that you can check off for a sense of completion
Take sensory breaks when feeling overwhelmed by textures, sounds, or smells
Use preferred lighting levels - bright task lighting or softer ambient lighting as needed
Allow extra time for transitions between different types of tasks or rooms
